Albert Munsell was the first to create a reliable and widely accepted color naming system that helped to identify one color from the next. He used color bias and value and chroma to define each color. Before him, artists and scientists attempted it but never reached the depth and accuracy of Munsell which is still in use today. There are several ways to do this. One is to use one of the "color catalog" systems, such as Pantone (in which each color is assigned a code number - you just need to have the set of color samples with their numbers to understand what color is being identified. This is a very common way to specify color in a number of industries. Another way is to use one of the standard color coordinate systems, such as the CIE Lab coordinates (commonly used for reflective color) or Yxy or Yu'v' (more commonly seen when working with light).
